## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 154, 343]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 305, 908, 320]]<|/det|>
9231/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 327, 908, 343]]<|/det|>

3 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 468, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF10)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 782, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 329, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 908, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 908, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 507, 615]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 615, 908, 645]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 644, 608, 660]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 673, 608, 688]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 688, 757, 704]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = \ln (ax + 1)\), where \(a\) is a positive constant. Prove by mathematical induction that, for every positive integer \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 108, 608, 141]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{n}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{n}} = (-1)^{n - 1}\frac{(n - 1)!a^{n}}{(ax + 1)^{n}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 116, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 633, 92]]<|/det|>
The line \(y = 2x + 1\) is an asymptote of the curve \(C\) with equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 100, 546, 133]]<|/det|>
\[y = \frac{x^{2} + 1}{ax + b}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 152, 156, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 152, 480, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the values of the constants \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 425, 186, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 425, 532, 444]]<|/det|>
State the equation of the other asymptote of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 427, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 536, 153, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 536, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).  [Your sketch should indicate the coordinates of any points of intersection with the \(y\)-axis. You do not need to find the coordinates of any stationary points.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 87, 92, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 594, 120]]<|/det|>
Let \(S_{N} = \sum_{r = 1}^{N}(5r + 1)(5r + 6)\) and \(T_{N} = \sum_{r = 1}^{N}\frac{1}{(5r + 1)(5r + 6)}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 129, 156, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 129, 702, 149]]<|/det|>
Use standard results from the List of Formulae (MF10) to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[383, 154, 616, 177]]<|/det|>
\[S_{N} = \textstyle {\frac{1}{3}}N(25N^{2} + 90N + 83).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 157, 920, 175]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 735, 186, 754]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 735, 628, 754]]<|/det|>
Use the method of differences to express \(T_{N}\) in terms of \(N\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 736, 920, 754]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 608, 92]]<|/det|>
With \(O\) as the origin, the points \(A, B, C\) have position vectors

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 98, 620, 117]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j},\quad 2\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + 7\mathbf{k},\quad \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 125, 223, 142]]<|/det|>
respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 155, 156, 173]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 154, 608, 173]]<|/det|>
Find the shortest distance between the lines \(OC\) and \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 155, 920, 173]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Find the cartesian equation of the plane containing the line \(OC\) and the common perpendicular of the lines \(OC\) and \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 524, 92]]<|/det|>
The equation \(x^{3} + 2x^{2} + x + 7 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 106, 156, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 106, 566, 123]]<|/det|>
Use the relation \(x^{2} = - 7y\) to show that the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 131, 606, 151]]<|/det|>
\[49y^{3} + 14y^{2} - 27y + 7 = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 160, 339, 190]]<|/det|>
has roots \(\frac{\alpha}{\beta\gamma}, \frac{\beta}{\gamma\alpha}, \frac{\gamma}{\alpha\beta}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 78, 153, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\alpha^2}{\beta^2\gamma^2} + \frac{\beta^2}{\gamma^2\alpha^2} + \frac{\gamma^2}{\alpha^2\beta^2} = \frac{58}{49}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 537, 186, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 532, 520, 572]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\frac{\alpha^3}{\beta^3\gamma^3} + \frac{\beta^3}{\gamma^3\alpha^3} + \frac{\gamma^3}{\alpha^3\beta^3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 920, 556]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 808, 917, 825]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 341, 92]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 92, 579, 144]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{M} = \left( \begin{array}{ll}2 & m \\ 0 & m \\ 0 & 0 \end{array} \right),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 148, 272, 166]]<|/det|>
where \(m \neq 0, 1, 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 179, 156, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 179, 665, 198]]<|/det|>
Find a matrix \(\mathbf{P}\) and a diagonal matrix \(\mathbf{D}\) such that \(\mathbf{M} = \mathbf{P}\mathbf{D}\mathbf{P}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 73, 462, 92]]<|/det|>
Use de Moivre's theorem to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 101, 675, 135]]<|/det|>
\[\sec 6\theta = \frac{\sec^{6}\theta}{32 - 48\sec^{2}\theta + 18\sec^{4}\theta - \sec^{6}\theta}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 156, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 465, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence obtain the roots of the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 100, 609, 120]]<|/det|>
\[3x^{6} - 36x^{4} + 96x^{2} - 64 = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 127, 468, 146]]<|/det|>
in the form \(\sec q\pi\), where \(q\) is rational.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 146]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 683, 125]]<|/det|>
The curves \(C_{1}\) and \(C_{2}\) have polar equations, for \(0\leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\), as follows:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 131, 583, 176]]<|/det|>
\[C_{1}:r = 2(\mathrm{e}^{\theta} + \mathrm{e}^{-\theta}),\] \[C_{2}:r = \mathrm{e}^{2\theta} - \mathrm{e}^{-2\theta}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 183, 500, 202]]<|/det|>
The curves intersect at the point \(P\) where \(\theta = \alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 215, 156, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 215, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{e}^{2\alpha} - 2\mathrm{e}^{\alpha} - 1 = 0\). Hence find the exact value of \(\alpha\) and show that the value of \(r\) at \(P\) is \(4\sqrt{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 231, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 156, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 73, 479, 92]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C_{1}\) and \(C_{2}\) on the same diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 358, 154, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 358, 920, 393]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the region enclosed by \(C_{1}\), \(C_{2}\) and the initial line, giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 375, 920, 393]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 74, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
